I played a version of this game back in the early 90's and loved it then.  We had a single cannon shot to obliterate the landscape and attempt to destroy our opponent.  Shellshock Live includes over 250 weapons, I had hesitations that this would work.  Sometimes too much variety can be overload.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=624332808

Gladly this game has a massive grind to open up all the weapons.  I hate grinding in games, especially in PVP games.  So why do I think it is good in this case?  Well, the basic weapons are enough to enjoy the game to its full and recently the playerbase got a MASSIVE influx due to popular streamers publicising the game.  Meaning you are pitched against other players of same experience with same weapon loadouts.  I can imagine it could've been a problem with a small playersbase but not now.

Maybe preferably I'd like to have access to all weapons without a grind and be able to custom select which to include on the server I create or join a server that has a selection I like to play with.  250+ weapons is a LOT to get to grips with so maybe the devs have implemented their introductions in the best way.  Time will tell...

One thing I didn't realise with Shellshock Live was that the most popular way of playing isn't turn-based but actually phase-based.  So every player is setting their power and trajectory and deciding which weapon to launch at the same time.  The result is very little waiting time for other players!!  It keeps the game and the fun flowing extremely effectively.

Touraments have been added recently, I can't wait to try those!

The game is simple looking in design but the graphics are clean and effective.

I'll be spending a lot fo time in Shellshock for sure, highly recommmended!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ShellShock Live is a Steam adaptation for a web game with the same name. There are many things that are done much better in this version and those will be described below. It is a turn-based strategy game where the rules are simple: destroy the enemy tanks. Being easy to understand and fun to play, you have to try it out.

Pros:    This is an online game and the devs cared enough to transfer it to Unity Engine, not just leave it in Flash. That is a huge plus.
There are no microtransactions. I was very surprised when I found this out and I'm glad they decided to keep this out of their game. All of the weapons, skins and other things that are usually behind the paywall can be unlocked by playing.
Beside being microtransaction-free, this game is cheap by itself already.
Graphics are simple, colourful and very nice to look at.
The amount of weapons in this game is astonishing. Seriously, there are more than 200 of them. And above all, they get leveled up as you use them.
Both multiplayer and simgleplayer modes. Are you out of friends? No problem, you have 80 singleplayer missions to complete and you can also level up with them. Great!
You have a test map where you can freely try out all of the weapons without quantity restrictuons.
Leveling system. By playing, you get experience and when you get to the next level, you even get a point that can be spent on your skill tree.
A lot of game modes and maps. You can play team deathmatch, player deathmatch, who deals the most damage ...
There are random wormhole and bumper spawns that prevent people from firing with the same angle and power over and over again. That is good in case some is locked on you and is hitting you repeatedly, but it comes with a pretty bad bug. See cons.
A cheaper 4-pack. Great if you have friends to play with.
Linux and MacOS support
Cons:    Well, the amount of people that are playing is quite small. There are very few servers and even those are usually full so you need to wait a lot or have friends that are ready to play.
Remember the microtransaction-free part of this review? Well, you can get everything without playing, but you get things painfully slow.
Singleplayer missions are divided into 8 sets. This would be fine, if you wouldn't need to complete all the missions in the previous set to unlock the next one. If you just can't figure one mission out, you are pretty much stuck with multiplayer.
Those obstacles that can bump bullets away can sometimes spawn on players, making them impossible to kill. It can be pretty unfair at the moments. Screenshot
The final verdict:This is a great game and doesn't require much practice to be extremely good at. For example, I have played against players level 48, 24 and 30 and I won the round. My level was 4 at the time. It's a pretty addicting game and it's fun to play. The two biggest flaws are a small player base and long matches. Other than that, I had a lot of fun with this game.
If you are not sure about buying, you can try the game here[www.shellshocklive2.com]. If you like the game, you should totally buy the whole game on Steam. It comes with more levels, weapons and with some Steam features integrated.

Greetings,
Bird

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ShellShock Live:
~~~~~~~~~~~~

Phew, his bouncing attack missed me twice! Hold on, you little red tank, you - let me get the right angle, power and a devastating weapon to wipe you off this map! Oh bugger! Not only did I miss him, but I managed to exterminate my teammate! What a shock . . . it is ShellShock Live after all!

ShellShock Live is an action multiplayer game where you take control of a cute little green tank in battle. This game is primarily a multiplayer game but it has a campaign mode which includes 81 missions to beat. The campaign mode will help you to understand the game and weapons.  Importantly, it will show you how to get the right angle for your shell to hit your enemy at the end of its trajectory in order to inflict maximum damage. You will be able to level up and unlock several weapons, maps and parts. Each time you level up, you will be rewarded with a token which you can use to upgrade the chassis, the track, the gun and even the luck of your tank.

When you are ready to fight online, you can create your own game or join an existing game. Most of the games I played online were 4 vs 4 but you might get to play 8 vs 8 if you are lucky. I must warn you, it was mayhem! Well, I was constantly targeted with some insane weapons! As you enter a game, you will spawn on one side of the map with your teammates and your opponent will spawn on the opposite side. Then you will have 45 seconds to move your tank to either a better and safer position or leave it where it is if you are happy with the location. The next turn (also 45 seconds) you will start fire shells or be the recipient of the enemy projectiles and so on and so forth until one of you is the last tank rolling! You might manage a maestro hit on one of your enemies and a golden gear might appear on the map - make to collect it as soon as possible. You will use the golden gear at the gear shop to buy addition gizmos.
A fair number of people are playing ShellShock Live online and it is very easy to find and play a game; on top of that the community is very friendly too. You also have a leader board and you can even create your clan.

Graphically the game looks good and it runs very well and I have not experienced any drop-out online. This is a fun, addictive game with plenty of re-playability

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Fun and addictive game
-	100’s of weapons and maps to unlock
-	Good number of upgrades and tank customization
-	Great value for money
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Random obstacles within turns can be painful at times

ShellShock Live is a great multiplayer game! Very addictive and seriously fun!

9/10

Early Access Review

If you've ever played the flash versions of this game, you'll love this one!

From the very two shellshock live games on flash, i became hooked. But not in a bad way at all!

This simple, yet fun game isn't very demanding in terms of computer specs, it manages to still look great even on it's lowest quality settings it offers. But when it's quality settings are set to the maximum it allows... It looks simply stunning and beautiful is all i can really say.

Features: Multiplayer.
Single player (campaign).
Robust graphics when set on the highest quality.
New HUB.
Over 58 maps to choose from! I think, i counted but i could be wrong.
Customizable tanks.
Use items to get a little upper hand on your enemy.
Up to 8 player battles.
Team Death match, and Free for all to play against your friends.
Over 200 weapons!
More things to come as this game is updated!

The gameplay: The gameplay is different from the first two previous games. You'll notice that the power of your shots are much more powerful if you've ever played the previous flash versions of this game. But don't allow that to deter you from purchasing this wonderful game! Sure it's hard at first to master the way you shoot, but after some practice you'll be good as you were before. And if you're completely new to the game, don't worry a thing. it doesn't take long at all to learn the mechanics of the game.

A little info about the game:
The single player campaign has 80 missions to do, some more hard than others. You'll have a tough time with them garuanteed. Some require you to really think hard on how to succeed in them but don't worry it's not impossible some have already beaten all of that already!

When you first start off you won't be able to do many things such as move as far as others when you join a match, don't worry this is normal. You must earn these things called ''Tank Tokens'' you obtain these from leveling up that you may use to upgrade your tank. You can choose to upgrade your tank as you see fit choosing from ''Chassis'' ''Armor'' (which also allows for the possibility to regenerate armor), Gun (chance to deal more damage to enemies), ''Track'' (let's you move faster and climb up and down down hills), and ''Luck'' (this helps you get loot from crates such as weapons, and armor).

You can use items to help you out a little these are the items.
Tracer: This item allows you to see where your shot will land before you shoot it, helpful if you're unsure about the shot you're about to take.

Teleport: This item is new and was not in the previous shellshock game, it can teleport you anywhere on the map randomly.

Jetpack: This item allows you to jetpack to a location within the radius that the item allows you to.

Shields: Pretty sure this one is self explanatory, but i'll go ahead and explain anyways. This one engulfs you in a small bubble that protects you for one turn from all weapons. The weapon earthquake is an exception.

Supply drops: When using them item you will see a small box float down from above your tank which provides you with random weapons.

EMP Blast: This one is also new, currently this item messes with the enemy's aim.




Final conclusion:
I would recommend this game to anyone who wants to just have a good time with friends, and likes to play something simple, fun and a little addicting once you get into it. So if you do get this game i hope you'll have as much fun as i do when i play it.

PLEASE READ BEFORE LEAVING THE PAGE OR BUYING. While you get way more value over ssl2, it requires so much grinding to unlock everything. But at least you don't have to pay $300 for it all!
The game's still in beta and needs a lot of work! A tough job for just one man. Even now, the developer is continuing to update the game with bug fixes, new game modes, new weapons!
There are so few players it's difficult for everyone to find a game. Most of the few including myself who went and bought the game early are now high levels, making it difficult for new players to grow. But that's why I'm advocating this game here on Steam! So we can have more players and hopefully all the new players will be able to find a game with people of their level! I so desperately want this game to grow. It's 5 freaking bucks, what are ya waiting for! If you don't like it you can get your money back!
The aiming is different than ssl2! Now it takes less power to shoot farther. If you were good at arcing in ssl2, you're gonna have to relearn those angle numbers. But it's very easy to adjust! You're going to find the aim makes more sense than in ssl2. Certain weapons have been nerfed and buffed. For example nuke did over 100 on ssl2, now it does 80 on steam. Napalm did around 88 dmg without crit on ssl2, but now it can do well over 100 depending on your upgrades. But maxing out your barrel yields a much higher chance of crit hits than putting several coins on a crit barrel on ssl2 which is probably why the nerfs are there. Some weapons that have been made weaker become very op with a maxed barrel!
There's still many weapons missing from ssl2 that are not currently in the steam version. Spligger, EE bomb, fast forward, zits, phantom, moon ball, bullseye, supersniper, drill bits, kamakazi, anvil and some others I can't remember. But there's some cool new weapons too!
The way you unlock weapons is different. First you have to unlock the first tier of a weapon, then you have to keep using it to unlock the next tier and so forth. For example you start out with a digger. Keep using it to unlock mega digger. Keep using that and you unlock excavation! So instead of just using the strong weapons and ignoring the weak ones, the game basically forces you to use everything so you can get a well rounded arsenal. The kicker though is that while you may unlock higher tiers it's still possible to get lower tiers in the mix. For example, if you unlocked excavation, you're still gonna get regular diggers sometimes. The tank leveling system is also different. In ssl2 there are 50 levels, then you can prestige and restart to lvl 1. On steam there's 80 standard levels. EDIT: new update caused a change in ratings (weapons)
I've followed the franchise since its inception, but I will try to be as unbiased as possible.  All reviews are at its current state; I firmly believe they can be 10/10s by the official release.

Single Player (7/10)

Single Player was a nice addition to this version.   It is a great for first time players as it introduces a large selection of weapons and strategies.  Players are forced to learn about and take advantage of essential aspects of the game such as portals, bumpers, items, etc.  As an introductory tool, it is fantastic.  My two only two concerns are something that can and likely will be fixed, but currently need to be addressed: opponent AI and mission amount/replayability.  At first the opponent AI was something that just was sort of funny at first, but by the later missions people can easily win by taking advantage of it.  Quite simply, if you put the computer opponent in a hole, they will shoot themselves over and over.  I do not think this is a pressing issue, but it is something that would be nice if it were fixed.  Secondly, it would be nice if there were more missions (or replayable ones).  Again, this isnt extremely pressing and is likely to be added in the future.  Perhaps have a daily challenge (ex: beat mission 8-6 in 5 tries or less for 10 gears!)

Weapons (7/10)

The weapons look great.  They are fun and unique.  They are built for different situations which makes strategy more interesting.  However, there are two somewhat pressing issues.  First, is the leveling system.   The current system is fun, but once you level a weapon it is unlikely you will ever use the old version again.  Thus, the endgame weapon pool isnt that large.  I'm not sure exactly how this can be fixed.  One idea is once a weapon is unlocked it becomes independent from its older version (they are separate, you can get both in one game for an example).   The second issue is weapon balancing.  Particularly, the close range weapons.
EDIT: So I took about the part about the OP close range weapons.  In the recent update, many were nerfed to do about half of what they use to do, which is a step in the right direction.  It also shows the developers are listening to the community.  There is still more balancing to be done, but these weapons were the main ones that needed to be changed, so balancing is not super urgent anymore.

Multiplayer (8/10)

Like I said, I love the portals, bumpers, items, maps, all that kind of stuff.  Multiplayer is pretty nice in its condition.  8 player games were added which is extra fun.  The only thing I dont get is what happened to points mode.  It was a good mode if you wanted to play a longer game that worked just fine in the online versions, not sure why it was removed.
Just as a side note, I disagree with everyone complaining about the slow leveling system.  The game has been out for a few weeks and you're ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that you're only 15% of the way to max?  If the leveling system was made faster, then you all will be complaining that more levels will need to be added after max.  Be patient young jedis!

Other upgrades (9/10)

Skill tree is awesome.  Maybe add a little more juice to luck (gears in boxes?).  Gear shop is brand new but looking great.  Not too many tank customizations, but that can be easily added.

Overall (8/10) (remember, this is for current state!)

I just want to add something, especially for people who have never played.  This game is not some action intensive adventure.  In fact, it can get quite boring if it is all you do for a few hours.  Whats great about this game is that it does not demand so much attention.  Its the perfect distraction.  Once of my favorite things to do is to watch a sports game on tv and play this at the same time.  You dont even really have to think to play this; I played this during the 7 hour redsox-yankees game and was like I wasnt really even paying attention to my computer

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review last updated: 5/18/2015 (mm/dd/yyyy), Shell Shock Live Early Access v0.9.1.2

Shellshock Live is the much anticipated reboot of the free to play flash game Shellshock live 1 and shellshock live 2 that personally I been having a lot of fun with in recent times.

Gameplay

To those coming from the previous flash versions of the game you will find that Aiming weapons is much more difficult to do in this version as all weapons have a different drop-off weight and how much power you put in your shot is much different compared to free to play versions of the game so it will take a bit of getting used too. One issue I been having is the traction as it seems very weird in this version as of the game, in the free to play version of the game even if you do have a low traction level you were able to go down any hills that aren’t at a 90 degree angle but you were unable to go back up that same hill without a higher traction level, where in this version you cannot go up or down most hills without the proper traction level which gets frustrating at times when you find yourself stuck on top of a hill as you are basically a sitting duck until the hill is destroyed enough for you to escape from. The portal mechanic is a welcome new feature that gives a whole new meaning to trick shots as they often enable shots that are usually impossible, possible if you aim well which is always impressive to look at.

The single player mission mode are a nice and very welcome addition to the game that enables new players to the franchise to slowly learn the basics of the game without jumping straight into multiplayer games unprepared, but I feel the difficultly curb goes up by huge spikes every set if you plan to go through them all at once with plenty of missions relying on perfect aim on a single attempt to complete without the assistance of the angle and power meter. Personally I feel this can be improved on by giving players more than a single attempt or at least give some tracers to assist the player as it can get frustrating with the lengthy trick shot missions. On the flip side if you put the missions to the side and level up your weapons a bit you can completely trivialize the difficulty of a lot of the missions. There should be a form of weapon lock system that only allows you to use the tier of a weapon that was originally meant for the mission or later mission additions won’t pose much of a challenge.

Shell shock live currently offers two different weapon system to choose from, one of them is the classic randomized weapon system that veterans of the series have come to know and love and the second is a selectable tiered weapon system each with its own set of advantages and disadvantages. Leveling up your weapons has also changed drastically compared to SSL2, instead of leveling up a single weapon multiple times for more power with that shot you now level weapons to upgrade them to superior versions of the weapons. The game also offers tank upgrading system, each time you level up you get an upgrade point for your tank which you can spend on either improving your traction, adding armor to your tank, adding higher critical chance to your tank, or just increasing your luck with certain aspects of the game.

Currently the multiplayer needs a bit of work because as of right now there are only a small handful of game modes to choose from which can cause the game to get stale after a while playing each of the modes. Finding a game can also hard at times due to the low but slowly growing population of the game, this is especially true if your one of the higher leveled players as a majority of the lower leveled players will tend to avoid you for good reason. Overall though the multiplayer is very enjoyable to play though it could use a couple of new game modes to mix up gameplay.

Training used to be very sluggish, but recently the exp required to level up was greatly adjusted to take out a large portion of the grind required to see everything the game has to offer which makes the game much more accessible to the casual audience while at the same time giving those more hardcore players that want to go beyond the traditional max level of 80 to grind the 20 additional prestige levels that will require tons of time and effort to achieve the real max level of 100. Though right now you might want to hold yourself back on grinding those levels as currently unlocks behind those levels are in development so there is not much reward currently for achieving the real max level aside from maxing out your tank.

The achievements can also be improved upon, for the most part I love the achievement system and I hope to see it expanded upon but I feel right now some achievements requires unrealistic amount of time and effort to obtain to unlock lack luster rewards if compared to the work required to get them. Usually I have no problem with achievements that require a lot of work to get but I feel they should be achievements for achievements sake with no rewards behind them and the more doable achievements having unlocks behind them.

Graphics and performance

The game looks very nice with all weapons and various effects having their own unique look and charm to them and also runs very smoothly on my computer, but I feel some weapons generate too much needless smoke sometimes. Another problem I have is the bloom, every shot and the background have a kind of bloom effect I feel is much too bright for comfort. Personally I feel there should be more options for adjusting certain graphical functions to optimize the game for computers that do not have the best specs because as of right now you don’t have many options and if you do not have the best pc to play this game with you will have no choice but to put up with the lag.

Community

The community is a very competitive one, but with competition comes toxicity so expect drama both in game and on the official forums. For the most part you can ignore these people by simply muting them or staying as far away from the drama as humanly possible, but I feel there should be a way to blacklist players from your games as there will be many times where people cause a lot of trouble for you by either quitting midgame because things are not well going for them or being generally disruptive in your game to the point where it ruins others fun. You are able to kick them from your room but that does not stop them from simply rejoining the room and the process repeating itself until either you finally let that individual in or they get bored and go elsewhere.


Conclusion

To new players of the franchise I would recommend playing the free to play flash version of the game first to get an idea what to expect with this game before buying it so you don’t come in with high expectations. If you are a veteran of shellshock live 2 give the game a shot but be aware currently shell shock live does have less weapons to choose from currently compared to the flash version of the game which will slowly be fixed over time but still don’t expect a large amount of new stuff. With the games recent price cut to the cheap price of $6.99 and the overall improvement to the game, community and developer involvement with the community I am much more prepared to recommend others to try out the game then I was previously. There is still lots of work to be done, I feel the single player mode should be expanded on with options other than missions and the addition of a local multiplayer mode with everything unlocked to play from the start so you can just grab a friend and experience everything the game has to offer without buying the game a second time and putting in the work required but of course that does not carry over to your actual multiplayer profile. Kchamp keep up the good work with the games development and continue to interact with your community as much as you have been lately to ensure the quality of your game only continues to only up.

Early Access Review

Firstly I'm going to preface this review by noting my experience with this game has taken place in the beta stage of development and things are, I assume, going to change with the full release.

ShellShock Live is a fun, pick-up-and-play tank game a la Worms, Gunbound, and my childhood favorite, Amiga Tanx--but you already knew that.  While there's obvious advantages to higher-leveled players (greater weapon selection, tank buffs, etc) the game is still strictly skill based and nailing cool shots is fun whether or not you win the round.  ShellShock Live is the kind of game you can pick up with your buddies and play one or fifty matches in an evening without so much as blinking.

As far as I can tell there is only one music track which, as epic as it is, gets annoying after the first five minutes--this is easily solved on my end by cutting the music off, but the inclusion of a few more audio tracks as the game approaches release would be a welcome asset.


Additionally, I would like to see the eventual incorporation of custom match modifiers / mutators where the host can select / ban certain weapons.  A Sniper only match, for instance, would be a heck of a lot of fun.

I've enjoyed my experience with ShellShock Live so far, and the few technical issues I've had were quickly and professionally rectified by the devs (specifically kChamp, thanks!).  I think the current pricepoint is completely reasonable, assuming that the game will continue to evolve and update without incorporating any pay-to-win elements.  Like I said before, the game is currently in beta and I hope to see many additions in the future as this game approaches official release.

If your looking for a review on shellshock you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Enjoy your meal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ShellShock Live for Steam already feels more complete than the first 2 pay 2 win games. The singleplayer really seems like it's geared towards teaching you how the weapons work without explaining it, rather it lets you experiment around to see how each weapon works. Some of the missions are hard for the wrong reasons (Lookin' at you, Get Lucky.), but generally you're in for a good time.

Now for the multiplayer aspect of the game (which let's face it, you'll probably get this for the multiplayer), it's about the same as ShellShock Live 1 and 2. You shoot other tanks until they die. There's no Points mode yet, but they make up for it in the currency called Gears. Gears are the equivalent of the Tank Coins in SSL 1 and 2. You get Gears when they pop out of tanks after they've been hit, and you mouse over them. Here's my only complaint so far: THE GEARS CAN OFFSCREEN THEMSELVES BEFORE YOU CAN REACT! If there's a tank to the very side of the screen, the gear will bounce offscreen and you won't be able to get it.

Now, this game isn't Pay 2 win like SSL1 and SSL2, but rather it's based on how much you level up, making it somewhat of a meritocracy. I like that. The more you play, the more experience (both in-game and actual experience with the game) you get, the better weapons you get and the more Tank Points you get. Tank Points are your stats, of which you can improve 4: your gun (attack power), your luck, your armor (defense), and your mobility. Each of this has a different advantage in battle, and provides for very unique builds.

I would recommend this to anybody who loves the idea of a 2D turn-based Tank MMO.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are familiar with the version on Kongregate.com and love it already then you won't be let down by this one.
The game may be in Early Acces, but it doesn't take away from the fun at all and has a lot to offer to its fans.

If you are new to the series but enjoy the genre of turn-based artillery shooters, then I can't recommend this game enough. It has enough to keep you trying to reach a higher level for new weapons and power ups.
The single player missions are nice, some offering a fair challenge and even occasionally cause some dickripping to occur.



I haven't encountered any bugs and haven't heard of any gamebreaking ones either, so far.

PRO's:

Online Multiplayer AND Singleplayer puzzles
Free For All, Team-based (Everyone shoots at once, team shoots at once, each player shoots on his/her turn)
Very polished (Kchamp has considerable experience, this being his third installment of the game)
CLANS for the competetively minded people out there
Easy to pick up and very casual. Great for a quick 15 minutes of fun!
Trickshots with portals and shields ;D
Plottwists, so many plottwists .. Turned a lost game around by hitting a 2X buff with a snipershot and have it critically hit on target after bouncing on a shield.
I feel the price is right.
Chat function in game lobbies and game itself, but no toxicity.

° New features are being added frequently °

CON's:

Game is in Early Acces, so everything stated and mentioned, including personal opinions, are prone to change
Due to Early Acces there is some waiting time for filling a multiplayer lobby, but this is barely an issue.
It's hard to think of any other cons, the game is really polished.

CONCLUSION: If you are a big fan of the last 2 games, don't hesitate to pick this one up! It's worth it!
Maybe even convince some friends to come and play together :D Or make some new ones like me.

Early Access Review

At a play-time of almost 2 hours (level 11 I believe), I've barely scratched the surface of this game, but one thing is for sure: I CAN'T stop thinking about the damn thing. The thrill of battle, the satisfaction of the progression, and the god-like feeling of landing a perfect snipe is addictive and so ♥♥♥♥ing worth it.  This is the definition of BANG for your buck.

In all seriousness:

This game consists of a single player with a set of 80+ missions that act as a tutorial and challenges, and a multiplayer mode against AI (but no xp gain) and human players. While the singleplayer is a nice way to hone your skill, the meat of the game is clearly in multiplayer.

There are quite a few multiplayer modes, but the most popular seems to be deathmatch, though I feel like the Assassination mode could be interesting as well. Players vary in skill level, which affects how many types of guns are available to them, and might affect their passive tank bonus. If you want to steer clear of the disadvantage of playing against high level players, you can either host your own lobby with a low rank difference, or seek out lobbies with similarly ranked players. You gain xp and level up regardless pf whether you win or lose (though more xp goes to the winner of course). I haven't had any problems with the multiplayer so far.

The game has a very satisfying sound and aesthetic. Guns appear in your roster with a flashy animation, and the presentation is very sleek overall. The only problem I have with the UI is the inability to click through the level-up or xp animations. These just take way too long, and I often have to click Ready while within the animation. This isn't hard, guys. Come on.

CONCLUSION: Costs as much as a sub. Provides endless hours of entertainment. Grab it now if you're a Worms fan, grab it anyway even if you're not.

Update: Completely changed the review to be more up-to-date on current events with this game.

Shellshock live is a MMO tanks game with tons of weapons and other customizable features. Cool. But you probably want to know more.

In case you did not know, Shellshock Live (SSL) is a steam adaptation to 2 free-to-play browser games, reasonably titled Shellshock Live 1, and Shellshock Live 2. Shellshock Live 2 is the newer and more active browser game, but the steam version (the newest adaptation) of this franchise has many differences than SSL2.

Q: if those browser games are free, why buy this game for $7?

A: It's based off what you want. All the weapons are found in both games, but here's the kicker: for $7, you get ALL the weapons. With Shellshock Live 2, lots of those weapons (and other things, but weapons are the main point imo) are locked behind paywalls (you can get 8 weapons for >$7. There are 8 of these weapon packs, and 2 retro weapon packs (from SSL1) that are twice the size and cost more). However, with Shellshock live Steam, it takes lots of GRIINNDDDIINNNGGGGG to get these weapons and upgrade certain weapons. (Im level 58/100 as of this review and i still dont have big shot) Thus, it's if you want to pay, or grind. If you pick SSL2, you chose pay. If you pick SSLS, you chose grind.
Now that that's out of the way, here are pros and cons for this game compared to SSL2.

PROS:

-No IAP (In-game-purchases)
-8 Player Battles (if you can get one going)
-Graphics! Graphics! Graphics!
-Early Access game...new features are being added more often.
-Clans
-Single Player mode (80 missions useful for newbies)
-NO IAP!!!!!@#$*!@*#%!@#*$%^&!#$TRQ@#111111 (sry)

CONS:

-Active people pale in comparison to SSL2
-The game isn't gaining many players currently
-S00 grindy
-Has weapon balancing issues (may be fixed, but we must wait.....)

All in all, this game is arguably in improvement on the flash version. I, myself, am really against In-game-purchases and find this to be a MUCH better value. However, it is much harder to create games than SSL2 due to the lack of people playing this game. For the price tag of $7, though, i find it to be well worth it. Plus, you're helping the community grow, right? :)

If you are a multiplayer-centric gamer, by all means give this game a try. I had hoped that it would replicate the frenzy and explosive insanity of Scorched Earth" from 1991 and for the most part it does.

Being unable to progress your "character" in strictly offline matches against the AI means that you are unable to experience the full range of customization and weapon options. There have been multiple requests for this feature since the game was in early access. This and the lack of local co-op when similar reboots of old franchises (such as Road Redemption) have included it suggests to me that the developers are more interested in unit sales than the experience.

It's not bad by any means

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ShellShock live, a fun little artillery tactical turn based shooter. Very similar to Worms, I liked the previous flash-based editions of SSL. The first two games are really classics.

PROS:
+Plenty of new weapons that can be leveled up
+Many maps that can be unlocked
+Customization of tanks (albeit through unlocks when you level up)
+Fun gameplay
+Good music

CONS:
-No offline skirmish mode
-Not enough players online

Despite these two cons I can think of it's whats holding me back from Recommending it. The single player has missions, and that's fun and all, but the lack of a skirmish mode to practice offline is really disappointing. Also the lobby feels empty most of the time and you'll be waiting a while to jump into a game with other players.

Most of the time the only way you'll be able to play multiplayer is through 1 on 1 matches which most of the time is unfair due to usually being matched against a very very high level player. They simply have more weapons, and more upgrades to make it less about skill involved and more about how much they have grinded to get there.

You can level up through the singleplayer but even when you beat all the missions your level will still not be enough.

TL;DR Shellshock Live is a Fun Tank game that's being Semi-worked on by it's developers and it's fun to play with friends, highly recommended for people who are itching for that 2D Tank Arcade feel.

ShellShock Live is the Remake of a Browser game with it's namesake, ShellShock Live 2. The game is completely redone in Unity and has 0 Paygates (As of the time of this Review 2/28/2016) unlike it's browser counterpart.

The game is pretty much your average 2D tank game, with the small exception of the XP system and the way you get new weapons. The weapons are gain by Leveling up, and you Upgrade said weapons by using them in battle, however you only increase the weapons XP if they deal damage, making some weapons Such as Moon Extremely Difficult to Level up.
There is also a Tank Level up system where you get a Token every level and you use said token to Upgrade your tank in the field you so desire (Gun, Movement, Luck, Chassis) Each of these Upgrades feel impactful with the exception of Luck, which i have seen no adverse effect of, and focusing on one Tree conversely makes it feel extremely Powerful, Such as gun and it's Crit Mechanic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR Version: The game is decent, you should check it out.

More indepth version: The game is pretty simple. What you see in the trailer is pretty much what you get. I've only played TDM and FFA so far (not counting the single player levels which I will talk about in a minute), and those play like that of or similar to a turn-based battle game. In FFA, all players (2-8 I believe) can choose to move, albeit only a few feet because if you could move anywhere that'd be too OP, and then choose what weapon you want to fire with and set the trajectory for the weapon to follow. Once everyone has done this and clicks the fire button, all the players will fire at once and if your guesstimate was good enough, you will hit your target and do some damage.
TDM is a little different in the fact that it's more turn-based styled and every player gets to shoot separately.
There are other modes but I haven't played them yet so I will not review/go over them.
Before I go onto the Single Player part, one more thing I will mention about the multiplayer for this part is that you can play with random people OR with any friends that you have in your friends list, which is awesome. Me and my two brothers have already played a few matches together and it's a BLAST. Get it? Blast...

There aren't always a lot of rooms open to play with/against other players and those that are open can be players that are much higher level that you so you wouldn't want to play anyway. For those situations there is the Single Player missions. There are currently 8 sets, each set has 10 missions I believe. As you'd expect, the beginning missions are easy, and comprise of easy tasks like shooting a target or destroying a couple of lower leveled CPU tanks. As you progress through the sets, the missions become harder. Like you have to preform trick shots with very limited ammo. It can become very frustrating but for those of you who like a challenge, this is great.

One more thing I will mention, as a pro, is the amount of weapons. There are TONS, each one unique and can be upgraded, 1 to 3 times, through use (it takes awhile). The charm isn't in the graphics or the tanks, it's definitely in the weapons. You can shoot cat bombs, summon lightning to strike your enemies, hell, even freakin guppies are a weapon in this game.

Are there any cons? Well, imo the game should be 5 bucks max as it looks and feels like something that could be played as a flash game online. (I remember playing something like this on the Lego Hero-ica website several years ago when I was younger hehe. Though it was only single player, it was a lot prettier...) It IS only 5 bucks now but only for a few days as a post this. Also, while there might always be some players online, there's definitely not always many. That being said, while it isn't a good thing that shouldn't stop you from playing. Because if everyone did that, no games would ever grow.

So, should you get it? It's really hard to say. Imo the game is a lot more fun when you play against other people, especially if they're friends. If you know anyone who has this or you have friends who are going to pick this up, I'd recommend doing it too.

(Sorry if my review isn't that great, it's not something I do very much :P)

I decided to try this game out, despite seeing numerous people complaining about it, and turns out I made the correct decision. A lot of thing must've changed, since most of those complaints seems not to apply anymore.

-The game is NOT multiplayer only. There are a LOT of single player missions/challenges that allow you to level up very fast, and unlock stuff quickly. You can also practice versus bots if you wish. I got to level 16 by playing an hour of SP, then trying out MP for the next hour. That got me enough weapons to have a very nice varriety in my loudout, and a couple of tank upgrade points for some minor bonuses.
-The progression system doesn't feel like it's making you so overpowered you can't live without it,  and there are also a lot of ways to make it less relevant. Sure, you won't ever win vs a lv 60 guy with your 5 level tank, but you'd probably lose anyway since he'd be way better as well. I got no problem playing vs level 20,30 players with my 15 level account, I still had tons of fun, and didn't feel like i'm at a disadvantage. Plus there are game modes that eliminate the disadventage of not having that many weapons unlocked (random weapon each turn),  or not being high level (FFA- pure chaos and fun).
-There is a decent number of people playing the game, I was able to find people on my level (+-5) in less than a minute, sometimes I even got into a very good lobby instantly, thanks to quick join function.
-This is not supposed to be played as a 1v1 game. If that's what you're after, forget about it. it's way too much random for a 1v1 game: you can get worse weapons, you can get worse starting position, you can get blocked by some random shield spawn on your trun etc. This is a game about diving into 3v3, 4v4 or FFA games and having a total blast blowing stuff up!


My advice: play some single player missions first, get the understanding of how shooting and weapons work, get some levels that way, and then jump into MP. I guarantee you'll have a whale of a time that way!

I love all the different weapons you get to choose from...and I think my favorite one is the Cat.  Meow!
Honestly, there's not much about this game that I cannot say anything bad about.  The spawning of the deflector rings and the deflector barriers is a little wonky sometimes, but that's easily overlooked with the simple fact that you're having quite a bit of fun trying to figure out the right tragectory of your shot while also figuring out either how to avoid the deflectors, or use them to your advantage.
And it's thanks to a certain favorite YouTuber of mine that I even found this game.  Were it not for them, I would have never found this beautiful nostalgic gem of a game.
Man, kChamp Games did a brilliant job recreating a childhood favorite of mine.  Kudos to the kChamps!

I decided to try this game out, despite seeing numerous people complaining about it, and turns out I made the correct decision. A lot of thing must've changed, since most of those complaints seems not to apply anymore.

-The game is NOT multiplayer only. There are a LOT of single player missions/challenges that allow you to level up very fast, and unlock stuff quickly. You can also practice versus bots if you wish. I got to level 16 by playing an hour of SP, then trying out MP for the next hour. That got me enough weapons to have a very nice varriety in my loudout, and a couple of tank upgrade points for some minor bonuses.
-The progression system doesn't feel like it's making you so overpowered you can't live without it,  and there are also a lot of ways to make it less relevant. Sure, you won't ever win vs a lv 60 guy with your 5 level tank, but you'd probably lose anyway since he'd be way better as well. I got no problem playing vs level 20,30 players with my 15 level account, I still had tons of fun, and didn't feel like i'm at a disadvantage. Plus there are game modes that eliminate the disadventage of not having that many weapons unlocked (random weapon each turn),  or not being high level (FFA- pure chaos and fun).
-There is a decent number of people playing the game, I was able to find people on my level (+-5) in less than a minute, sometimes I even got into a very good lobby instantly, thanks to quick join function.
-This is not supposed to be played as a 1v1 game. If that's what you're after, forget about it. it's way too much random for a 1v1 game: you can get worse weapons, you can get worse starting position, you can get blocked by some random shield spawn on your trun etc. This is a game about diving into 3v3, 4v4 or FFA games and having a total blast blowing stuff up!


My advice: play some single player missions first, get the understanding of how shooting and weapons work, get some levels that way, and then jump into MP. I guarantee you'll have a whale of a time that way!

Early Access Review

This type of game has existed for a very long time now, and many variations of it have come up on every platform.  I've enjoyed every single one thus far, but did eventually get bored of them.

This game, however, seems to perfect the long line.  This game has very nice and clean graphics while still being able to run on pretty much every system, it has enough weapon variations to keep one entertained, a sytem to keep players coming, and excellent customization in every area of the game.

The game customization and level system are what surprised me the most.  When a player sets up a game, they are able to choose the amount of players, map, game mode (which there are a surprising amount of), health, and other various items.  Then, as one plays the game, they see that they get experience.  Players level up as they play, which not only unlocks new weapons and maps, but allso allows allows the player to upgrade and customize their tank.  A player's tank can be customized to their liking, specializing in four different categories which boost different areas of their vehicle.  This feature pleasantly surprised me the most, and is exactly what keeps players coming back.  Even the weapons a players use upgrade as they use them.  The progression system adds so much to the game, and is a key feature.

The in-game chat system is excellent as well, with text bubbles of what a player says appearing above a tank, which can make for some funny conversations.

When I first saw the video before I bought the 4-pack I was worried that there would be a weapon or destruction overload.  It appearned that the game would be over in two or three turns with such destructive power, but it turns out that is not the case.  The weapons do get strong, but not game breaking especially due to the option to raise the amount of health that the players can have, which goes up to six times the standard.

Overall, this game is much more than I expected, with a good price tag, and lots of content to keep one entertained.  Playing with friends is an absolute must, and even when one can't play with them they can go single player or campaign.  The game feels almost complete and is still developing, and would recommend it to anyone, especially if they have friends to lpay with and/or they enjoyed the Worms series.
